methods.javadoc:
Constructor for Ghidra
 A new test project is established.
 If it already exists it will first be deleted.
@throws IOException if there is an issue creating a test project
methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Constructor for Ghidra
 A new test project is established.
 If it already exists it will first be deleted.

throws.comment: if there is an issue creating a test project

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Constructor for Ghidra
 A new test project is established using the specified projectName.
 If it already exists it will first be deleted.
 If the test environment is not disposed within 1 minute the tests iwll be aborted

throws.comment: if there is an issue creating a test project

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Constructor for Ghidra
 A new test project is established using the specified projectName.
 If it already exists it will first be deleted.

params.name: abortTimeout
params.comment:
number of minutes within which this test environment must be
 		  disposed.  If not disposed in a timely manner, System.exit will be invoked.

throws.comment: if there is an issue creating a test project

methods.javadoc:
This constructor allows clients to manage their own projects. Also, this constructor will not enforce having only a single env instance running, which allows for multi-project testing. All other constructors will enforce that a single instance of TestEnv can be running at one time, closing any previously opened instances before finishing construction.

Note: this constructor is meant for subclasses. @param project the initialized project
methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
This constructor allows clients to manage their own projects.  Also, this constructor
 will not enforce having only a single env instance running, which allows for multi-project
 testing.  All other constructors will enforce that a single instance of TestEnv can
 be running at one time, closing any previously opened instances before finishing
 construction.

 Note: this constructor is meant for subclasses.

methods.javadoc:
Get the tool associated with this test environment.
@return the default test tool for this environment
methods.name: getTool
methods.comment: Get the tool associated with this test environment.

return.comment: the default test tool for this environment

methods.javadoc:
Closes the TestEnv's default tool.  This method is asynchronous, so you
 must wait for the Swing thread to perform the work yourself.
 Watch out for modal dialogs.
methods.name: closeTool
methods.comment:
Closes the TestEnv's default tool.  This method is asynchronous, so you
 must wait for the Swing thread to perform the work yourself.
 Watch out for modal dialogs.

methods.name: closeTool
methods.comment:
Closes the given tool.  This method is asynchronous, so you must wait for the Swing thread
 to perform the work yourself.  Watch out for modal dialogs.

methods.name: addPlugin

throws.comment: if there is an exception adding the given tool

methods.javadoc:
Shows any previously created tool, creating a simple empty tool if not tool has yet been created.

This method is considered sub-standard and users should prefer instead {@link #launchDefaultTool()} or {@link #launchDefaultTool(Program)}. @return the newly shown tool
methods.name: showTool
methods.comment:
Shows any previously created tool, creating a simple empty tool if not tool has yet 
 been created.  
 
 This method is considered sub-standard and users should prefer instead 
 #launchDefaultTool() or #launchDefaultTool(Program).

methods.name: showTool
methods.comment:
Shows any previously created tool, creating a simple empty tool if not tool has yet 
 been created.  The given program will be opened in the tool.
 
 This method is considered sub-standard and users should prefer instead 
 #launchDefaultTool() or #launchDefaultTool(Program).

methods.name: waitForDialogComponent
methods.comment:
Waits for the first window of the given class.  This method is the same as
 #waitForDialogComponent(Class, int) with the exception that the parent
 window is assumed to be this instance's tool frame.

params.name: ghidraClass
params.comment: The class of the dialog the user desires

params.name: maxTimeMS
params.comment:
The max amount of time in milliseconds to wait for the requested dialog
        to appear.

return.comment: The first occurrence of a dialog that extends the given ghirdraClass

methods.name: createDefaultTool
methods.comment:
This method differs from #launchDefaultTool() in that this method does not set the
 tool variable in of this TestEnv instance.

methods.javadoc:
Launches the default tool of the test system ("CodeBrowser"). This method will load the tool from resources and not from the user's Ghidra settings.

Note: Calling this method also changes the tool that this instance of the TestEnv is using, which is the reason for the existence of this method. @return the tool that is launched
methods.name: launchDefaultTool
methods.comment:
Launches the default tool of the test system ("CodeBrowser").
 This method will load the tool from resources and not from the
 user's Ghidra settings.
 
 Note: Calling this method also changes the tool that this
 instance of the TestEnv is using, which is the reason for the existence
 of this method.

methods.javadoc:
Returns GhidraProject associated with this environment
@return the project
methods.name: getGhidraProject
methods.comment: Returns GhidraProject associated with this environment

methods.javadoc:
A convenience method to close and then reopen the default project created by this TestEnv
 instance.  This will not delete the project between opening and closing and will restore
 the project to its previous state.
@throws IOException if any exception occurs while saving and reopening
methods.name: closeAndReopenProject
methods.comment:
A convenience method to close and then reopen the default project created by this TestEnv
 instance.  This will not delete the project between opening and closing and will restore
 the project to its previous state.

throws.comment: if any exception occurs while saving and reopening

methods.javadoc:
Launches another default tool, not overwriting this env's current tool.
@return the new tool
methods.name: launchAnotherDefaultTool
methods.comment: Launches another default tool, not overwriting this env's current tool.

methods.name: getGhidraCreatedTools
methods.comment:
Returns an array of tools spawned by the Ghidra environment.
 NOTE: This array will not contain any of the TestTools!

return.comment: an array of tools spawned by the Ghidra environment

methods.name: restoreProgram
methods.comment:
Copies the specified program zip file to the JUnit test project's root folder. This
 means that the program will appear in the FrontEndTool as part of the project.  That is
 the only reason to use this method vice openProgram().

params.name: programName
params.comment: the name of the program zip file without the ".gzf" extension.

throws.comment: if the program file cannot be found

methods.name: restoreDataTypeArchive
methods.comment:
Creates a project data type archive in the indicated test project folder from the ".gdt"
 file indicated by the relative pathname.

params.name: relativePathName
params.comment:
This should be a pathname relative to the "test_resources/testdata"
 		  director or relative to the "typeinfo" directory. The name should
        include the ".gdt" suffix.

params.name: domainFolder
params.comment: the folder in the test project where the archive should be created

return.comment: the domain file  that was created in the project

methods.name: saveToCache
methods.comment:
Save a program to the cached program store.  A SaveAs will be performed on the
 program to its cached storage location.

params.name: replace
params.comment: if true any existing cached database with the same name will be replaced

methods.name: isProgramCached
methods.comment: Determine if specified program already exists with the program cache

return.comment: true if specified program already exists with the program cache

methods.javadoc:
Remove specified program from cache
@param programName the name
methods.name: removeFromProgramCache
methods.comment: Remove specified program from cache

methods.name: getProgram
methods.comment:
Open a read-only test program from the test data directory.
 This program must be released prior to disposing this test environment.
 NOTE: Some tests rely on this method returning null when file does
 not yet exist within the resource area (e.g., test binaries for P-Code Tests)

params.name: programName
params.comment: name of program database within the test data directory.

return.comment: program or null if program file not found

methods.javadoc:
Launches the default tool of the test system ("CodeBrowser") using the given program. This method will load the tool from resources and not from the user's Ghidra settings.

Note: Calling this method also changes the tool that this instance of the TestEnv is using, which is the reason for the existence of this method. @param program The program to load into the default tool; may be null @return the tool that is launched
methods.name: launchDefaultTool
methods.comment:
Launches the default tool of the test system ("CodeBrowser") using the
 given program.   This method will load the tool from resources and not from the
 user's Ghidra settings.
 
 Note: Calling this method also changes the tool that this
 instance of the TestEnv is using, which is the reason for the existence
 of this method.

params.name: program
params.comment: The program to load into the default tool; may be null

methods.name: launchTool
methods.comment:
Launches a tool of the given name using the given domain file.
 
 Note: the tool returned will have auto save disabled by default.

methods.name: launchTool
methods.comment:
Launches a tool of the given name using the given domain file.
 
 Note: the tool returned will have auto save disabled by default.

params.name: toolName
params.comment: the name of the tool to launch

params.name: domainFile
params.comment: The domain file used to launch the tool; may be null

methods.name: setAutoSaveEnabled
methods.comment:
Sets the auto-save feature for all tool instances running under the FrontEndTool
 created by this TestEnv instance.  Auto-save is off by default when testing.

methods.name: loadResourceProgramAsBinary
methods.comment: Import a program as binary.

params.name: programName
params.comment: resource name that is the name of the program

methods.name: loadResourceProgramAsBinary
methods.comment: Import a program as binary.

params.name: programName
params.comment: resource name that is the name of the program

methods.javadoc:
Release a program which was obtained from this test environment.
@param program the program
methods.name: release
methods.comment: Release a program which was obtained from this test environment.

methods.javadoc:
Special code to make sure that the tool used by an AutoAnalysis manager instance is removed. This prevents the accidental re-use of the wrong tool between test runs. (Why? Well, the AA manager has a static map of tools and it sometimes picks tools to use based upon which GUI window is active, which when the current window is not active, can cause the wrong tool to be used for a test, which means that a disposed tool can be used, which prevents AA from running).

This code is our use of inside knowledge to cleanup testing artifacts.

Note: if each test fired a 'program closed' event, then this wouldn't be an issue, but they don't. Further, doing that here has ramifications with threading and timely closing of the test environment. So, rather than fire an event here, we will just do our magic.
methods.name: cleanupAutoAnalysisManagers
methods.comment:
Special code to make sure that the tool used by an AutoAnalysis manager instance is
 removed.  This prevents the accidental re-use of the wrong tool between test runs.
 (Why?  Well, the AA manager has a static map of tools and it sometimes picks tools to
 use based upon which GUI window is active, which when the current window is not active,
 can cause the wrong tool to be used for a test, which means that a disposed tool can
 be used, which prevents AA from running).
 
 This code is our use of inside knowledge to cleanup testing artifacts.
 
 Note: if each test fired a 'program closed' event, then this wouldn't be an issue, but
 they don't.  Further, doing that here has ramifications with threading and timely
 closing of the test environment.  So, rather than fire an event here, we will just
 do our magic.

methods.javadoc:
Opens the given program in the test tool.
@param program the program to open
methods.name: open
methods.comment: Opens the given program in the test tool.

methods.javadoc:
Closes the given program, ignoring all changes, for each tool known to this TestEnv.
@param p the program to close
methods.name: close
methods.comment: Closes the given program, ignoring all changes, for each tool known to this TestEnv.

fields.javadoc:
Used to perform emergency cleanup.  Tests are expected to call {@link #dispose()} in
 their <tt>tearDown</tt> method.  This is here to catch the case where the is some fatal
 error that prevents that from taking place.
fields.name: instances
fields.comment:
Used to perform emergency cleanup.  Tests are expected to call #dispose() in
 their tearDown method.  This is here to catch the case where the is some fatal
 error that prevents that from taking place.

fields.javadoc:
A list of tools that have been created by instances of this class that will be
 disposed of at cleanup time.
fields.name: extraTools
fields.comment:
A list of tools that have been created by instances of this class that will be
 disposed of at cleanup time.
